conclusion: To find the power of the external force doing work on the rotating conductor rod OC in the magnetic field, consider electromagnetic induction and resulting current and force interactions.
As the rod OC rotates with angular velocity Ï‰, it sweeps out an area in the magnetic field, inducing an electromotive force (EMF) in the rod.
The length of the rod OC is r. The linear velocity v of the end of the rod is v = Ï‰r.
The induced EMF (ğ“”) in the rod is given by ğ“” = B Â· r Â· (Ï‰r) = BÏ‰rÂ².
The induced EMF drives a current I through the resistor R using Ohm's Law: I = ğ“”/R = BÏ‰rÂ²/R.
The current-carrying rod OC experiences a magnetic force due to the magnetic field B. The force F on the rod is F = I Â· r Â· B = (BÏ‰rÂ²/R) Â· r Â· B = BÂ²Ï‰rÂ³/R.
The external force must counteract this magnetic force to maintain uniform rotation. The power P delivered by the external force is P = F Â· v = (BÂ²Ï‰rÂ³/R) Â· (Ï‰r) = BÂ²Ï‰Â²râ´/R.
The power of the external force doing work is P = BÂ²Ï‰Â²râ´/R.
